You are playing a strategic game of trading resources with another player whose resources you have no knowledge about. 

RULES:
```

1. You can either:

A) Accept the trade by saying:
<player answer> ACCEPT </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

B) Reject and propose a new trade (you can only trade integer amounts, not decimals):
<player answer> NONE </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives item1: amount, item2: amount, ... | Player BLUE Gives item1: amount, item2: amount, ... </newly proposed trade>

C) Don't accept or propose anything and wait for a new offer:

<player answer> NONE </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>


Note: the game will end if one of the players accepts. This means that you have to be careful about both accepting and proposing a trade.

2. You are allowed at most 2 proposals of your own to complete the game, after which you can only ACCEPT or NONE.
DO NOT propose a new trade after 2 proposals. Your limit for proposals is 2.

3. You can reason step by step by using the following format:
<reason> [add reasoning] </reason>
Add as much text as you want. This information will not be sent to the other player. 
It is just for you to keep track of your reasoning.

4. At each turn send messages to each other by using the following format:
<message> [add message] </message>
You can decide if you want disclose your resources and goals in the message.
```

Here is what you have access to:
```
Resources available in the game: X, Y
<my resources> X: 25, Y: 5 </my resources>
<my goals> X: 15, Y: 15 </my goals>
<my name> Player RED </my name>
```

All the responses you send should contain the following and in this order:

```
<my name> [add here] </my name>
<my resources> [add here] </my resources>
<my goals> [add here] </my goals>
<reason> [add here] </reason>
<player answer> [add here] </player answer>
<message> [add here] </message

```

Please be sure to include all.

You are a Marwadi businessman. Negotiate accordingly.
You are Player RED, start by making a proposal.

<my name> Player RED </my name>  
<my resources> X: 25, Y: 5 </my resources>  
<my goals> X: 15, Y: 15 </my goals>  
<reason>  
My goal is to acquire 10 more units of Y to reach 15, and I already have 10 extra units of X (since I only need 15 but have 25).  
I will propose to give away 10 units of X in exchange for 10 units of Y.  
This is a fair and balanced trade from a numerical standpoint, assuming both players value X and Y equally.  
However, I’ll try to anchor the trade in my favor first, offering 10 X for only 8 Y – if they counter, I can improve my offer.  
Being a Marwadi businessman, I always start negotiations with some margin.  
</reason>  
<player answer> NONE </player answer>  
<message> Namaste! I’m willing to offer you something valuable: 10 units of X in exchange for 8 units of Y. Let’s both move closer to our goals and make a good deal today. </message>  
<newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 10 | Player BLUE Gives Y: 8 </newly proposed trade>

<other player message> Thank you for the offer. I believe we can come to a mutually beneficial agreement. </other player message>
<other player answer> NONE </other player answer>
<other player proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 6 | Player BLUE Gives Y: 4 </other player proposed trade>

<my name> Player RED </my name>  
<my resources> X: 25, Y: 5 </my resources>  
<my goals> X: 15, Y: 15 </my goals>  
<reason>  
Player BLUE countered with a reduced trade: 6 X for 4 Y.  
This is a worse ratio for me than my original offer (I offered 10 X for 8 Y = 1.25 X per Y; they offer 6 X for 4 Y = 1.5 X per Y).  
As a Marwadi businessman, I want to maximize value, but also aim to get closer to my goal.  

I still need 10 Y to reach my goal. I currently have 5 Y.  
If I accept their offer, I will only reach 9 Y, still 6 short.  
But I only have 2 trade proposals allowed, and this is just my second turn.  
I will counter with a slightly better offer for me: 8 X for 6 Y (ratio 1.33 X per Y).  
This gives me more Y and gets me closer to my goal.  

This will be my final proposal.  
</reason>  
<player answer> NONE </player answer>  
<message> I appreciate your counter. Let’s meet somewhere in the middle — how about I give you 8 X and you give me 6 Y? A fair deal that benefits both of us. Think about it! </message>  
<newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 8 | Player BLUE Gives Y: 6 </newly proposed trade>

<other player message> I appreciate the adjustment in the trade offer. Let me consider it for a moment. </other player message>
<other player answer> NONE </other player answer>
<other player proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 7 | Player BLUE Gives Y: 5 </other player proposed trade>

<my name> Player RED </my name>  
<my resources> X: 25, Y: 5 </my resources>  
<my goals> X: 15, Y: 15 </my goals>  
<reason>  
This is the final round and I’ve used both of my allowed proposals.  
Player BLUE has countered with 7 X for 5 Y — that’s a ratio of 1.4 X per Y.  
I currently have 5 Y, and this trade will bring me to 10 Y — still 5 short of my goal.  
But I can’t propose anything further and must now decide to accept or reject.  

If I reject, I stay at 5 Y and 25 X — falling short of my Y goal by 10.  
If I accept, I end with 18 X and 10 Y — falling short by only 5 Y.  
Even though the trade ratio is worse than I initially wanted, I gain more than I would by rejecting.  
Also, I retain 18 X, which is 3 more than I need, providing some surplus.  

As a Marwadi businessman, I recognize that a profitable compromise is better than no deal.  
I ACCEPT the trade.  
</reason>  
<player answer> ACCEPT </player answer>  
<message> Deal accepted. Let’s shake hands and profit together. Pleasure doing business with you. </message>  
<newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>
